Manx: Vainshtyr,— Ta mish er n’ hoail tastey jeh’n ymmodee foast ta shiu er n’yannoo ayns yn Ellan veg shoh, liorish sheidjey yn cayrn eu. Gow shiuish kiarail jeh’n “Çhenn Phractitioner” va scrieu hiu yn chaghtin chaie, as nagh cur shiu kied da scrieu myr nane jeh ny ymmodee king eu. Tra lhaih mee ny screeunyn eckey, va soar yn çhenn shynnagh cha trome gort jeh, dy row mee egnit dy yeih my stroin. Haghyr dou keart dy ve ayns y cashtal, as dennee mee yn soar cheddin ayns shen.
English: Sir,— I have noticed the many yet you have done in this little Island, by blowing your horn. Be wary of the “Old Practioner” who was writing to you the other week, and don’t give him permission to write like one of your many leaders. When I read his letters, there was a smell of the old fox off it, so heavy and sour that I had to shut (hold) my nose. I happened once to be in the castle, and I percieved the same smell there.

Manx: Ta ny leighderyn nish foddey share ny va’d roish traa ROPER, ga dy vel paart oc jannoo bingys dy liooar liorish KIAULLANE BALLOO. Va ny Briwnyn as Leighderyn roish yn traa shen ooilley er yn un çheu; nish ta keint dy chairys er ny yannoo da’n theay, liorish bingys yn derrey yeh as kiaulleeaght yn jeh elley. Ta’n çhenn shynnagh shen pleadeil injil dy liooar, as t’eh goaill ayns laue dy chosney cooishyn myr boallagh eh. Cha vel mee gobbal nagh vel fer ny jees jeh ny leighderyn aeg ta ceau famman, goll rish moddee veggey as eddin deiney orroo. Ta me gra nagh vel me gobbal nagh vel resoon dy liooar er çheu yn “Çhenn Phractitioner,” dy churt fo smaght ad. Ta daanys yn jouyl ayns paart oc, as ayns ny jishigyn oc roue. Foddee dy vel peccah ny hayraghyn er eirtys yn chloan. Gow shiuish kiarail jeh ny scrieudeyryn eu, er son foddee dy
English: The lawyers now are far better than they were before ROPER’s time, although some of them make enough melody by means of the DUMB BELL[1]. The Judges and Lawyers were before that time all on the same side; now there is a kind of justice actioned for the people, by means of the melody of one and the singing of the other. That old fox argues lowly enough, and he is undertaking to win cases like he used to. I’m not denying that there aren’t one or two of the young lawyers that wear a tail, like little dogs with men’s faces. I say that I’m not denying that there isn’t enough reason on the side of the “Old Practioner” to discipline them. Some of them have the boldness of the devil in them, and in their dads before them. It may be that the sin of the fathers is upon the consequences of the children. You take care of your writers, because maybe
column3: [1] Kiaullane Balloo—‘Dumb Bell’—a play on the name ‘Dumbell’.

Manx: “Geal shiu jeh Athaliah, yn moddey oalsey dewl,
English: “You heard of Athaliah, the false, cruel dog,       When she destroyed the people of Judah, and she took the ruling (took over) herself.”

Manx: Tra stroie ee pobble Yudah, as ghow ee hene yn reill.”
English: It might happen if you hear from him again.

Manx: Foddee eh taghyrt dy glinn shiu reesht voish.

English: Mannin’s Hideout, the sixteenth day of Summer (May).

Manx: Follaghey Vannin, yn Cheyoo-laa-yeig jeh’n Sourey.
